Recording car audio subwoofer could offer a much easier start (lots of movement and low frequencies; perfect for a fairly low speed footage). This could help adjust the software. I know it's not quite the same thing but pretty close and it allows you to adjust the volume and with that, the amount of movement; from minimal; similar to what they get with Al foil, to very visible; millimeters or even a few cm. Also, various objects or surfaces could be attached to the speaker's cone to see how they behave (maybe even with different lighting conditions) and this could also help improve the software.

Also; Applied Science has made a video, where he was able to record music from vibrations of a window of a room where the sound source was located. He used reflected laser light as a way to capture the movement.

From the beginning of the video there was one thing bugging me. Video is just the flow of several pictures. So, you hear the sound because of the moving objects. But in a photo, it just captured 1/infinite th moment, which is a still position of the object and the objects around it at that particular time. So, the sound won't come. Only when the motion occurs, sound comes. So, in a picture, the movement of the molecule are literally in no motion. So, relative to that picture, it is just a piece of image which shows what exactly happened in that 1/infinite th of the time. So, even if the molecules were moving, it atleast takes time. The thing is that, we don't recognize it. And, an image shows the state of objects in that particular 1/infinite th time, and the molecules are still. So, there can't be any possible ways to take sound out of a picture.
Think like this,
You are able to take sound out of a picture. So what does it actually mean?? It means that, the sound which we have extracted from that photo, is the sound which was going on when the picture was taken in the 1/infinite th of a sec. And, if the sound extracted was a 5 sec clip, then it means that the 5 sec audio was playing in just 1/infinite th second. Does it really make sense?? This is just a total NON-SENSE!

For the foil test you could use a foil membrane over the speaker with the shiny side up. Then you point a light to reflect of the foil and into the camera. Then as the speaker moves the amount of light received by the camera would change in correlation to the compression and rarefaction. Then you could correlate light levels to sound waves since it should be a very clear distinction. It's the same that was used here. But this way you can be certain that your camera will pick it up the first try.

Very interesting video.  Sure, the sound signal is subject to Nyquist sampling constraints.  Each observation from the image is effectively the output from a planar microphone.  Consider taking observations from >1 spot from the images.  Observing multiple vibrations of the planar microphone across the surfaces will effectively multiply the sampling frequency by the number of observations.  The  wave pressure will be smeared in time across the image at the speed of sound.   It might be possible to reconstruct some directional information as well by noting the progress of the wavefronts across the scene.  Microphones arranged across multiple planes (e.g. x-y, y-z, x-z), will observe different signals.  It might be possible to improve direction-finding accuracy by modulating the orientation of the planar microphones (like a dog cocking its ears).  Since you know the medium (sound in air at some temperature), you are also getting information about how observed signals vary over time..
In other words, the FBI, CIA, NSA, and Stalking Stan just got new toys

The shower speaker probably doesn't have great output, or a very wide frequency range. Low-frequency waves have a much better tendency to kinetically affect objects. That shower speaker isn't going to be able to faithfully replicate a genuine, in fact, the best shower speaker I could find dropped off severely at 100hz, so if you're trying to play tones at less than that like you are in this video, that little shower speaker is really just trying to approximate that tone so that it sounds about right to human ears, but might not actually be producing much a 60 or 80hz wave.

If you've still got the high framerate camera, try doing this experiment by placing the foil on some big studio monitors, or even the cone an old subwoofer. If you can actually replicate the lower notes, you'll probably have an easier time extrapolating audio data from pixel movement.

That's not exactly why we sample at 44.1Khz in music ... the reason we do that is due to aliasing, we'd still hear the signal at 22khz sample rate it'd just have a lot of aliasing in, we wouldn't just NOT hear anything like you suggest. However you are right, it's the same problem you encounter when trying to film vibrations as described in Nyquist–Shannon sampling theorem, it's just because you are working with such low frame rates that you will not see any movement at a frame rate corresponding to one cycle of pretty much the LOWEST perceivable sound frequency possible.

If you were recording footage at say 20kfps, even though the human hearing reaches only 20khz normally, you will not NOT perceive any motion, even though it's not double the frequency of the sound. You will have a "perfect" reconstruction (limited only by the capturing method's quality it's self) of frequencies up until 10Khz, and aliasing upwards of that. It would only be at exactly 20khz that it would appear as dead still, everything below would be aliased between 10khz and 20khz and "perfectly" captured below that.

That being said, and me not being an expert, I would expect the frequencies you could recover would be about 1/2 of the frame rate, or a little below, and this would depend on some surface in the video being vibrated enough to be detectable. I would expect that in order to recover human speech with some degree of quality, you would need a frame rate of around 4,000 frames per second, which would allow you to capture the most common frequencies in human speech. Again, this depends on a surface in the video being vibrated strongly enough to be detectable. The most common frame rates, from 29.95 frames per second up to about 60 frames per second would most likely not yield usable results. This is my guess, based on what little I know. To easily work with low frequency sounds you have to multiply the recorded extracted sound to increase its frequency using a frequency shifter like used in submarines.

To remove the noise from recorded video pixels use a low pass filter on the video, like a temporal noise remover.
It removes low fluctuating video brightness over a period of time (many frames) like buzzing neons or flashing light bulbs.
You can sample a 30 fps video with a 30 hz sound using multiple recording and phase delayed startup recording.
Like filming an atomic explosion, the cameras a the time cannot film 1000 fps. so the used many 100 fps with a phase delay of 1ms between them to cath in between frames.
You can amplify the motion using a laser a mirror to of course. But this would not be using a ordinary recorded video.

Certainly higher frequencies could be captured with much more computation.  "Compressive sensing" uses a single pixel camera to reconstruct images by focusing on a random reflection of the image.  I don't remember the specifics, but they can reproduce wavelengths with fewer samples than the Nyquist rate.  This required knowing the random reflection pattern, and calculating the probability of each pixel based on what the single sensed pixel recorded.  This would work with images too, but would require the processing to take into account the movements at different parts of the image based on different frequencies.  I suspect it would be very challenging, probably requiring a specially designed vibrating object.  Small foils for higher frequencies, etc.

And even the below method I mentioned about a waveform graph would be a round-about way of spying on your conversations. Your biggest threat to your audio privacy (assuming you are an average guy, not a high level government employee) isn't a spy with a high speed video camera, or somebody who installs malware to convert sound into a picture on a computer screen (which actually would draw attention to the spy's activities because seeing a waveform graph suddenly on your computer screen would be a quick giveaway, so this would actually be an unlikely spying technique anyway). Instead, the biggest threat to your audio privacy, is going to be malware on your computer, that activates your microphone and then sends a live audio stream back over the internet to the hacker's computer. THAT is actually the BIGGEST audio spying risk, BY FAR, that you need to worry about. The best way to be safe from that, is to simply not click links in strange emails, and have a good antivirus software installed on your computer.

There IS a way to convert an image back to sound though, and that is if the sound is FIRST converted into an image. If you used special software to convert the sound into an image, specifically a waveform display, and then have your computer display segments of that waveform display on the screen at a slow enough rate that a normal video camera can record it, then the saved video file could be later analyzed by custom software, and an audio file generated from the processed video file. This could be effective if a spy installed malware (maybe via social engineering, tricking the target to run the malware installer) on a computer that listened via the microphone, and then displayed a waveform on the screen.

If that computer monitor was visible through a window outside the building, then the spy could stand outside the building and record the computer monitor with his camcorder, and then take the recorded video back to his base and run his own custom software to process the recorded video back into sound.

Simple answer, you can't, at least not the way this guy is doing it. And here's why.

The bandwidth of a video camera is WAY too low. Voice audio tends to include frequencies between 200Hz and 6000Hz. I've discovered through lowpass filtering sounds in audio software on my PC, that if you cut the highest frequency too much below 6000Hz, the human voice starts to lose intelligibility, ESPECIALLY for letters like S that have a high frequency noise component. If you are using this as a spying technique, you will need to have a camera that can record oscillations up to 6000Hz. Of course, due to the Nyquist limit, if you want a bandwidth of 6000Hz, you will need a sample rate of 12000 Samp/Sec. The sample rate of a video camera is called its frame rate, and MOST cameras don't have a frame rate of 12000fps. Most consumer cameras have video recording at either 30fps or 60fps, and are completely useless for recording most audio (having bandwidths of 15Hz or 30Hz, meaning either no audible sound or only the lowest frequency audible sounds possible).

Some expensive professional digital video cameras (like those used to film Hollywood movies, costing in the range of about $5000 to about $50000) may have a setting in its configuration menu that would let you set it to record ad frame rates up to 120fps, or 240fps in rare cases. Even that though, would at best allow you to hear sounds up to 120Hz. This cuts off all but the lowest frequencies of the human voice, and wouldn't allow you to hear any words a person spoke.

To do this experiment properly, your camera would need to record at up to 12000 fps, and that would require a dedicated high speed scientific camera. You'd be LUCKY to find one at less than $10000, and they can easily cost over $100000 for the higher end ones.

I actually have a decent Nikon digital camera, the Nikon1 J5, which is a consumer-level camera and cost only $500, and it has a high speed video recording setting that lets it have speeds up to 1200fps, which is still only ONE TENTH the required framerate to do this experiment properly. Its bandwidth is only 600Hz, and regarding voice audio, would produce only a very low-pitch "mumbling" sound for the human voice. You would not be able to make out ANY words the person was saying. And due to the huge amount of data this recording mode generates, it depends on an internal high speed RAM buffer in the camera to immediately record the data from the image sensor, before later saving it to the SD card for permanent storage, after the recording has finished. This internal RAM is relatively small, and allows only 3 seconds of recording in this mode (though upon playback at normal 30fps speed on your computer, it runs for 2 entire minutes). Even if the 600hz bandwidth somehow were enough for certain tasks, it only allows recording 3 seconds at a time, which makes it basically useless for audio spying, where you would want to run a continuous recording session during the entire conversation you were trying to eavesdrop on.

I recall seeing a short documentary of success that Russian scientists and the KGB had in reconstructing sound. It was developed in order to reconstruct private, sometimes classified, conversations among various western industrial, scientific, governmental, security, and intelligence personnel. It was far more sophisticated in its methods than what is nicely portrayed here. I found the Russian method brilliant, beautiful, and stupendous technologically. It required meetings taking place in rooms with large glass windows. The basic method was to measure vibrations, extremely tiny, in the glass plates of the windows caused by the speech in the room. To do this, clearly, extreme sensitivity to tiny relative movements is required. This was accomplished with low intensity blue frequencies laser light, although use of lower resolution IR frequencies was eventually perfected, since the blue frequencies ones had to be set down to very low intensity not to be visible to the participants in a meeting. The technique fundamentally used multiple lasers directed at different points on the glass, and not just simple bounceback from the glass. Rather, the technique used the interference patterns of the light reflected from various pairs of the lasers. Comparing different pairs and isolating the interference patterns common to two or more pairs would eliminate extraneous sounds (like street noise). It was brilliant, they worked out the technical challenges, and it was fully capable of reconstructing good sound. Damn the Russkies! However, one simply has to praise their physical sciences and, perhaps even more so, their mathematics. Many reading this will recognise some fundamental similarity of this technique and those used to produce holograms. The ability of interference patterns to capture truly exquisite detail is outstanding.

5:30 the reason we use 44.1kHz sample rate (and not 48kHz which is used in film production) to record music, is because of the property of a digital recording to have his frequency specter duplicated at his end. This phenomenon was discovered by Claude Shannon (and Nyquist), his theorem point out that in digital recording, we need twice the information we can perceive in order to have enough room to apply some filtering and remove the duplication. So, as we ear frequency between 20Hz and 20kHz, we’ve chosen 44,1kHz. I hope this is understandable. This comes from the misunderstanding of how a A/D converter works, if you’re interested, search for Sigma-Delta conversion and you’ll find the truth. You can't recover sound from images. You can, however, recover sound from a mute video clip, but due to sound frequencies being much higher than image frequencies, the recording has to be in too high quality for practical use.

Not sure if you guys have taken this into consideration, but there are some hidden factors that you might be overlooking where some of them are related to quantum mechanics. One issue is the doppler effect of sound itself which doesn't really involve quantum mechanics directly as this is just a property of sound over time and moving objects. However, the camera, the object of observation, and the audio source are all static or stationary so this shouldn't have a major impact and may be disregarded in this particular case. It should still be a consideration for other environmental setups. Another topic that you might need to take into consideration is the property of the fact that objects absorb sound and the fact that sound dissipates over time and distance traveled along with the density, temperature, and pressure of the medium in which the sound is traveling through or into. One of the major issues that need to be taken into an account that does pertain to quantum mechanics is that of Photons and the Act of observation itself. How objects react to light and the presence of an observer human or nonhuman such as a camera or a sensor can have an effect on the overall behavior of the system. Besides all of this, I do like the concept of this experiment and the overall direction in which it is heading. I do tend to believe even without evidence that there is some truth and possibility to your original hypothesis and theory. If Sound didn't imprint on objects that it travels through then we wouldn't remember those that we love and care about, we wouldn't be moved by music to our liking and the such, and we wouldn't be able to have the ability to hear or listen in the first place! Our memory cells within our brain record these phenomena and process them so that we are consciously aware.

Title is kinda misleading even though it's technically accurate. You are recovering sounds from a video not really "images".
Images seem to refer still images not a video (which is like thousands of pictures combined together).
I was kinda baffled when I heard the title because I thought there was gonna be some super intelligent technique to get sound from stills. What the video actually shows is basically video taping the vibrations from a driver and reverse engineering it. Video would be alot color if we see the exact reverse engineering process rather than a display of a ln existing concept.
Furthermore, stereophonic tech has been around since 1930, and recording tech since the 1880's. It would be much easier and accurate to record sound through a mic than through a video. With a mic, the vibration is induced/conducted directly onto the diaphragm. There's alot less variables and it's much more practical. Using images on the other hand is not practical nor is it accurate. The sound travels and vibrates to a piece of object (losing energy depending on the material) and the same time as the camera is trying to pick it up, other variables come into play like that picture noise mentioned in the vid. It's highly impractical because it requires an object within the location of noise and requires a high quality camera to look at the object. Data saved are huge because they are images and takes time to decode and reverse engineer. Compared to the microphone where it is small, compact, recorded data is small and analysis is simple, I can't see how the concept from the video is practical at all.

In fact, the laser microphone has already utilized this effect in a degree already, by using lasers to detect sound vibrations. It's accuracy is way beyond this technique and much more practical. This video is basically redundant.

About your allusion to the Nyquist sampling rate.  It isn't actually true that twice the sampling rate recovers all audible sound.  The ear is not a linear receiver.  Hence, sounds above 20k beat against each other to produce lower frequency artifacts on a person ear drum.  These are missing from low pass filtered and digitally sampled sound.  This might explain some of the 'color' that some people note is missing from digitally reproduced music.

There were very fine  lines on this vessel in a circular path around the circumference , they surmised it was a hand held instrument/tool,,much like an awl,  thin and sharply pointed, used for the purpose of decorating it.   They put the pot on a turn table and used a laser to follow the grooves closely..   they translated the motion of the grooves into sound,,  they found it was the sound of the potters wheel being inscripted into the soft clay during its production, much akin to a record player. This is an interesting insight for me.I do digital communications on cruise ships and I had a very interesting chat to an old man who used to do a form of surveillance that used only AUDIO! This was in the OLD days. They would set up stereo microphones all over a town, then digitally squash the sound and bring it to a central hub, where an "algorythm"/mixer would bring to the front any sounds that were out of the ordinary. So if a car were to drive through the town its "noise profile" would be passed on incrementally and not be flagged. But a gun shot, scream, alarm, etc would immediately flag the system and just by measuring the audio you could almost exactly pin point the event. They had a lot of success but it was dropped because the amount of data and sampling rates were too much to use and store in those days and the sampling and analyzing in busy areas took some time to process. Imagine combining these technologies. That would be super powerful if you could use other frequencies as audio inputs too

5:01 - Veritasium, great video, but I have one comment regarding your explanation. You say that having a camera that shoots at 30fps will miss most of a 30Hz signal and that it will only capture only 1 point in the signal (with the same amplitude) every time.

However I believe this is wrong (from your explanation per example). Having 2 signals (let's say f0 and f1) each with the same frequency, the only way they will intersect (which is essentially the recording) in the same point over and over again is if the two signals are not synchronized. So, the first signal would have f0(0) = 0 but the second signal would have f1(0.5) = 0, that would mean that the recording function (f1) would always intersect f0 at the same amplitude point throughout time -> what you're drawing.

If you have a 30fps camera and a 30Hz signal, you can capture that signal completely, if you start the recording at t0 when the signal starts. However, synchronizing the two functions is very difficult and that is why the sampling rate increases, so you could capture more points with your recording function so that you can get the relative frequency of your source signal f0.

In the end, the problem is not with frequencies being different or the same, but with the starting point in time of the recording.

You are wrong.
The sound moves at a constant speed in air.
You need a BASE == BROADCAST pitch/sound to synchronize all the sounds based on their location.
Choose a "highly visible" base sound from your sample.

This will allow you to create a 3D MESH /SHAPE of the object you are filming in order to extract sound.

Then - knowing the displacement in time of each pixel (based on the position it is on the 2D image frame you CAN extract MORE frequencies.
Then recombine the sound frames in the right order.
then you have a high-frequency sample to analyze.

@5:28, sampling at twice the frequency will not give you the correct result. You must sample at more than twice the maximum frequency that is present in your input signal. Otherwise your sampled data will be corrupted. Sampling produces aliasing. Any signal at Fs will appear in your sampled data as a signal at zero Hz. Any signal with a frequency above Fs, such as Fs + d, will appear in your sampled data as a signal with a frequency of d. To avoid your sampled data from being corrupted, when sampling at 2 Fs, you must make certain that there is no measurable signal at Fs or higher.

Great video and reminds me of an experiment I one did a long time ago using a laser, and a Photodiode. You could effectively listen to conversations inside buildings at long distances. I achieved this by bouncing the lasers reflection off of the largest window I could find on any structure, then capturing the reflected laser onto the diode. The diode's electrical current would then modulate as the reflection bounced across the diode. The larger the glass, the greater the amplitude of those modulations. You could turn any piece of glass into a giant microphone using this technique. The best part is, it's very cheap and easy to replicate. I believe they ended up commercializing these devices as laser listening devices.

once they were in the computer, they were able to turn the computer speakers into a microphone (physics-wise, they're basically the same, magnets and coils, he just recorded the input)
they realised the 'microphone' was picking up the receptionist's keystrokes, as well as the head honcho's typing. by figuring out which key, on whose keyboard, was being pressed, they got his login details, and were able to hack deeper into the system.

I suspect recording off a diffuse but high contrast object will give less noisy results due to the fact that glossy materials highlights are highly sensitive to object rotation so would likely introduce unnecessary noise to the signal. Something like a paper cube printed with black and white checker pattern might give a good result.  The more correlated the changes are to linear motion and the less they are correlated to the unrelated object rotation, the more representative of sound the result should be. That being said, it could be that the higher sensitivity due to reflection could be necessary to receive enough change in luminosity to get any signal at all.

is this right..?
•Sound's frequency hit the Foil
•Foil made tiny vibration reacting to that's frequency
•Camera record the foil's vibration
•You zoom in and take frame by frame (images)
•Each frames have different pixel's colors (which that tells the foil's vibration)
•Special software converting that pixels compilation into sounds
•Software done it and the result it give 2bit sound
•A 2bit copy version of sounds that hit the foil

So basically you read sounds through Image's Pixels changes.
Which is that way how you can hears sounds even it covered by sound proofed glasses, cause camera still can take the images.

Many years ago I came up with a similar idea, for listening to people behind glass windows a long distance away, with a laser. The tricky bit is that you have to align the laser close to 90° to the window, or alternatively bounce it off the window at a set angle so you can place the receiver for the bounced beam in a more convenient position. The frequency of the laser modulation will change slightly as the sheet of glass moves back & forth as the sound from people's voices strike it. Demodulate the reflected laser light and that gives you something pretty close to what someone was saying in a closed building hundreds of metres away.

Simple yet little known fact of science - the vibrations induced by sound waves will easily modulate the light reflecting off the affected objects. I made a device that will pick up the sound of insect wings simply from reflected or transmitted light, from 50 feet away under ideal conditions, and we're talking tiny bugs like gnats as well as all the bigger critters. It also translates atmospheric distortion from heat, the sizzle of objects burning in a flame, the sound of a car stereo vibrating the car's headlights, the spray of a fountain, stuff like that, and it works very well. All the sounds that are produced sound like the real world sound equivalent. It's pretty neat, fun stuff.

You don't actually need a higher framerate camera, you just need more data. You can easily extrapolate the noise over time, and there's tonnes more mathematical principles that you can use not only to make it clearer but also to find the frequencies you're looking for faster.
You're looking for repetitive changes within a certain frequency band. Changes in the image due to background light/movement aren't going to look anything close to changes from sound. Other light changes will be completely random and won't repeat. You should only be looking for repeating changes in the frequency range of roughly 4khz to 8khz (assuming you want vocal sounds. PS you could look at a far smaller frequency range). Sound is very predictable and different to other background interference.
This would take someone about a week to turn into a 100% perfect piece of software that could extrapolate all sound within the bounds of the pixel and colour sensitivity of the camera, and regardless of framerate (and barely contingent on the length of the video. Not many videos are less than 6 seconds, which is plenty).

And on a more general note, if you wanted better results from the exact test you did right here, you should have just made a thin cone of foil instead of pinching it into a ball.

A 30Fps sampling rate should only be able to give you a maximum of 15Hz sound accurately, according to the Nyquist theorem. However, you could make a video of an object that is extended in space in the direction of the sound-waves - then take into account the speed of sound, particularly the delay between two most distant parts of the object. As the speed of sound is 343m/s, at 30Hz each frame will show a 11.43m long part of the sound wave. If you filmed an 12 meters long object with 10 equally distant reference points on it (or 10 separate objects arranged in a 12 meters long queue) you have just multiplied your sampling frequency by 10, to an effective 300Hz, being able to measure sound up to 150Hz. If you had 100 such reference objects 12 centimeters from each other then you increased your sampled sound frequency to 1500Hz. At this frequency even human speech would be reconstructable. While still using a 30FPS camera. Of course this would only work if the object was not affected by echoing sound waves in the room, so in a properly sound-insulated room.

This is kind of lame. I know a man who, about 30 years ago, stretched a very thin foil over a ring about 1" in diameter. He then shined a laser on it and picked up the bounce with a little light to current transistor and viola! a fidelity that surpassed the most expensive microphones. He then filed for a patent. The patent was granted, but he was not notified about that from the patent dept. but rather from a US National Security bureaucrat who told him that the patent was granted and then siezed by the govt. According to the laws the govt had to purchase the patent and he had to sell it to them so they could be lawful owner. Govt paid him $800 and classified the technology as top secret, which included a gag order on him. They didn't say why it was being classified but he had a good guess: He had generalized the patent to cover bouncing the laser off any surface that acted like a membrane, and had, before filing, actually tested on many materials including window panes. Turns out he bounced the laser at 45 deg off a house's window pane from 50 ft away and was able to clearly hear conversations inside the house. I remember the man had claimed that the laser was modulated at some frequency and that was fairly critical be he didn't reveal the number.

On another occasion, which working at a clandestine defense department facility, where I had the lowest of possible clearances, I was accidentally in the room when a demonstration was given of a mind-boggling technology. No, not anti-gravity or full cloaking or anything that far out, but still it was mind boggling. It quite obviously had tremendous commercial potential but is still unknown except to a few and that was about 25 hears ago.

US govt, and probably USSR, China and Japan govts have tech way beyond anything we know.

There was another way to get audio without a microphone I read about in a Radio Electronics magazine wayyyy back in the early 1980s.  And that was by bouncing a laser off a window from several miles away.  The laser basically records the vibrations of the window and translates them into audio.  The window basically becomes a giant microphone, and really, that's how microphones work!  It's how our ear works.  Microphones simply vibrate which effects a magnetic coil.  Our ear is the same, it records vibrations.  In this case, you're checking the vibrations of objects, a laser, which is VERY accurate, can measure the window etc.

No offence guys but look up laser microphone. They’ve had this technology since the 80s.

A laser microphone is a surveillance device that uses a laser beam to detect sound vibrations in a distant object. It can be used to eavesdrop with minimal chance of exposure.

The object is typically inside a room where a conversation is taking place and can be anything that can vibrate (for example, a picture on a wall) in response to the pressure waves created by noises present in the room. The object preferably has a smooth surface. The laser beam is directed into the room through a window, reflects off the object, and returns to a receiver that converts the beam to an audio signal. The beam may also be bounced off the window itself. The minute differences in the distance traveled by the light as it reflects from the vibrating object are detected interferometrically. The interferometer converts the variations to intensity variations, and electronics are used to convert these variations to signals that can be converted back to sound.

A couple of factors to consider during this video. The foil was shaped purposely to a specific shape for both so called “tests”. Therefore, if a person shaped a flexible object to mimic the sound that is attempting to be captured through a photograph, the results would have been created, but not actually produced if that makes sense. Shaping a foil to have shorter ridges here and longer ones there would be for the extent of the notes played throughout the beat of a song in terms of quarter notes, half notes, whole notes etc. The foil was not rolled into a ball shape and if it was, then perhaps the test would have had a different outcome which would not have been a biased one in my opinion. This test was altogether counterintuitive considering of course sound can be heard from an image seen and or witnessed. For instance, imagine this, if a car were to be blasting music and the bass of a song was moving the entire car in such a way that a noticeable movement could be seen, but not heard as say you were wearing headphones, and if say the cars motion and bass of the song were to Queen’s “We Will Rock You” then, someone who recalled the beat could conclude that the movement of the car resembles the beat of the song. Furthermore if a person were singing a song and you bear witness to their performance from a car away as they appear to be lip syncing, the movement of their lips would help you identify the song they are actually singing despite the fact that you could not actually hear the song playing in their car. These men knew the song that was playing first off and we do not know if the foil was first off shaped to mimic short note ridges and long note ridges here and there. How the frequency was captured and then produced into a graph like red photo with hits of yellow on screen @ 8:28 was never truly explained. All we hear as viewers is that there was a mysterious code used. I would need to see this experiment redone while the person testing the theory simply receives a photograph of still frames, not having heard the song played, and thus needs to decipher the sound and beat coming from photograph using the motion caught within still frames.

As someone who used to do these kinds of processing several years back, it’s useless (before completely focusing on power electronics, I used to do signal processing. Mostly ultra sonic applications for industries such as nut sorters).

1. The vibrations are tiny
2. More importantly the camera filters everything
3. Assuming that the camera captures a perfect 30Hz, your sound recovery will be limited to 15Hz.

4. Even if you do all sorts of super advanced processing to utilize a plane of pixels to compensate for the nyquist rate by recovering in both time and space, you still won’t get any good predictions for anything higher than 100Hz.

Awesome video! But I noticed a small discrepancy in your explanation of the Nyquist theorem which I wanted to point out. You said that for a sound to be captured you have to sample it AT LEAST twice per cycle, when in reality, it has to be sampled any amount MORE than twice per cycle. The reason is that, for a frequency of n, a sample rate of 2n could by chance capture the wave exactly at each zero crossing or close to it, resulting in either a silent or very quiet recording. It’s a small distinction but I think it’s important because it shows the incredible accuracy of digital audio sampling. Because of this principle, even with a sample rate of 2.0001n you can perfectly capture a sound with a frequency of n!

A really cool thing about this that the video sadly doesn't go into, is how higher frequencies are captured from low frame-rates. This video kinda implies that a 60 fps video can only get samples at 60Hz (and recover signals at 30Hz because Nyquist) but that's not so!

They exploit the rolling-shutter effect. That's the thing where digital cameras don't actually capture the whole frame at once. They take the first row of pixels, then the next, then the next, and so on all the way down the image. This means that each row actually represents a slightly different moment in time. The reconstruction software shown here can actually exploit that to see high-frequency movement within a single frame and capture some higher-than-frame-rate audio frequencies. With the camera setup used in the paper, they were able to recover about 2000Hz from a 60 fps video.

Here's one to explore. We know from Mythbusters that crashing two identical cars head on into one another at the same speed is the same as crashing each car separately into an immovable wall at that speed. The speeds don't add! But what happens if the masses and/or speeds of the cars are unequal? What happens when a 2,000 pound car and a 4,000 pound car collide head on at 50Mph? What if the lighter or heavier car is going 75 Mph or one is going 30 Mph? Can we expect a 2,000 pound car at 30 Mph to only have the damage of hitting a solid wall at 30 Mph if it's smashed into a 4,000 pound car moving at 50 Mph, and the faster, heavier car to not have any less damage than if it hit a wall at 50 Mph?

Or will the lighter just get splattered no matter what? Such a real world test will need a bunch of two sizes of cars, each size all identical, and a place to do controlled crashing. FOR SCIENCE! (And crashes, lots of crashes.)

I wonder if you could improve upon this? In an image, there will be multiple individual points vibrating and they will each have a different phase difference from the audio. You could probably use that to reproduce sounds at a higher frequency than the camera can record frames? So:
1. Identify and classify points on edges into n buckets where vibrate similarly
2. Determine the phase difference of each bucket (i can imagine this being the hardest step since you'd effectively have to score how likely a waveform produced by a given set of phase differences is to be correct)
3. Sum over each of the buckets in each frame and enjoy?

Big fan of this research! Seems like there is potential for applying this to human neuroscience as a potential model of cross-model perception [1]. Consider, for example, studies of associative learning and synaethesia [2], the projections of neurons between the primary auditory cortex (A1) and the primary visual cortex (V1) [3], the McGurk Effect [4], and these weird effects:

Bouncing tower gif induces illusory impression of perceived sound (in some people)
https://www.theverge.com/2017/12/4/16733778/noisy-gif-hearing-movement-auditory-neuroscience-synesthesia

Auditory-Flash Lag Effect
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D3Z1cxA2Tp0

McGurk Effect
https://www.youtube.com/results?search_query=mcgurk+effect

References:
1. Alais, D., & Burr, D. (2003). The “flash-lag” effect occurs in audition and cross-modally. Current Biology, 13(1), 59-63.

2. Yon, D., & Press, C. (2014). Back to the future: Synaesthesia could be due to associative learning. Frontiers in psychology, 5, 702.

3. Clavagnier, S., Falchier, A., & Kennedy, H. (2004). Long-distance feedback projections to area V1: implications for multisensory integration, spatial awareness, and visual consciousness. Cognitive, Affective, & Behavioral Neuroscience, 4(2), 117-126.

4. Hirst, R. J., Stacey, J. E., Cragg, L., Stacey, P. C., & Allen, H. A. (2018). The threshold for the McGurk effect in audio-visual noise decreases with development. Scientific reports, 8(1), 12372.

I read about this a while back. They dealt with the frequency issue in a really clever way, which wasn't made clear here. Cameras might only record 30 frames per second but each scan line, each row of pixels, is recorded much faster. Even with a 480p camera you are getting 14,400 lines per second (14.4KHz)- which is more than enough to pick up normal human speech. By comparing the change in each line to the preceding line as the camera scans down the frame (normalized by how different they were previously) you can get enough time resolution to pick up all but the highest frequencies.

This... could be dangerous.

The government use to use equipment that followed the "Tempest" standard, to avoid electronic ease dropping. Back in the old days, computer monitors used CRTs. With that technology a frame was sent serially, 30 times a second, to refresh the display. So if a spy could receive its electromagnetic (EM) emissions, he could see what was on the screen. Tempest was established, so that EM was contained with the monitor, and not emitted.


Leon Theremin, the same guide that invented the theremin, created a very successful ease dropping device, was installed in the US Embassy, in Moscow. It was a simple, mostly wooden plaque, gifted to the Embassy, by the Soviets. It contained a passive tuned circuit (inductor and capacitor) that was custom made to have those components properities, but not look like anything electrical. At 330MHz, simple brass trim becomes a very good inductor. I believe, the "capacitor", also acted as a microphone. If a constant level EM signal was beamed at it. As someone spoke, near that plaque, the tuned circuit would go in, and out of tune. This would effect how much energy it absorb from that outside EM beam, and the senders of that beam would detect the power variation (see grid dip meter), hence listen to that speech. Looking for active bugs, would not detect this device, as it was passive, and did not emit any power itself. Operated from 1945 to 1952.


https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Thing_(listening_device)


We use this technology today, in the form of RFID tags.

You should read sound off the video of a speaker generating the sound. One of the issues with getting high quality sound from a vibrating object is that the object is a major sound dampener--it doesn't put out the same amount of sound that went into it. You could say its sound albedo is very low. This means you may deafen yourself trying to record sound loud enough to get picked up in the video. But if you record a speaker, then the movement of the speaker is being generated by inaudible magnetism, and all of the sound you hear is actually generated by the movement in the first place, thus the sound from the video may be much more comparable to the sound you get directly from the speaker.

I think you missed one important point from the original paper. That is, even though ordinary cameras shoot at 30/60fps, not all pixels are recorded simultaneously. Like your old CRT TV, a camera scans line by line and has a rolling shutter effect (a.k.a. jello effect), therefore the effective frequency is much higher than 30/60Hz.

Back in the day, (40 years ago. Ok I'm older) we'd used a lens on a LASCR to "see"  laser light oscillate as it bounced off of a window. The oscillation was caused by talking inside the room on the other side of the window. The LASCR would "see" the changes in the laser reflection and with the use of an audio amplifier on the LASCR, we'd hear what was being said on the other side of the window with quite a bit of clarity. Analog, even with its limitations, actually has an infinite resolution as opposed to the resolution issues in the digital realm. Never tried your type of experiment with analog means (film) but that would be interesting to experiment with wouldn't you say? Film, even though it has grain, doen't suffer from limited pixels.

Wait a sec., all you’re talking about is efficiency of encoding.

Standard film encodes sound by varying the light transmission on the edge of the film. Getting sound info from deducing light variations from objects in the frame (instead of the mic voltage) is simply an inefficient form of encoding. Both are using variations in sound pressure to encode optical data.
